Issues.Title: Two ngcc fixes
Issues.Body:
This PR fixes two ngcc bugs:

* Some downlevelings of `export const DIRECTIVES = [...]` eliminate the `ts.Declaration`, causing ngcc to not enumerate them when listing the exports of a module.
* `.d.ts` files outside of the currently compiling package were indexed and used to match classes in the package. If such a `.d.ts` file shadowed the name of a class within the compilation, it could erroneously be targeted for editing.

With these changes, ngcc can compile `nativescript-angular`!

Angular elements

"Note that some polyfills (e.g. document-register-element) do not call the constructor. Do not assume this strategy has been created."

It then proceeds to add checks that the strategy is created in each of the callbacks.

It does not, however add the checks to the attribute [setters or getters](https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/23825/commits/a417ae43e39e87f64f8b7fe75f62c48508fd14c8#diff-ad5cb9ab336c13dbe9a23278e0299e62R186-R187).

set@........elements/src/create-custom-element.ts
```

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

Please let me know if you really need this.

I'm using the document-register-element polyfill and constructing my custom elements like this:
```ts
const node = document.createElement(SELECTOR);
node.attributeOne = "value one";
containerNode.appendChild(domNode);
```

Though I've placed the attribute assignment and the addition to the DOM next to each other, they're further separated in the application, and it would not be trivial to switch the order in which these operations are occurring.

# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages the are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> 
This feature request is for **@angular/common/http**


### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è-->

Let's say we defined an object containing a map like this:
```typescript
export interface MyObject {
  name: string;
  description: string;
  labels?: Map<string, string>;
}
```

We instantiate it with some labels and want to send it in an http post request
```typescript
this.http.post<AlertRule>(url.build(), myObjectInstance).pipe(
    catchError(this.errorHandler.handlerHTTPError)
);
```
The problem is that the object actually sent **does not contain our Map fields**.
```json
{
  "name" : "my-name",
  "description" : "my-description",
  "labels" : {}
}
```

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è-->
The solution would be to give a custom  ``replacer`` and ``reviver`` respectively to the ``JSON.stringify()`` ``JSON.parse()`` call like described in this post https://stackoverflow.com/questions/29085197/how-do-you-json-stringify-an-es6-map/56150320#56150320

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> 
My workaround right now is to defined my object like this, and it works, but I hope that angular http will support Map in bodies.
```typescript
interface StringMap {
  [key: string]: string;
}

export interface MyObject {
  name: string;
  description: string;
  labels?: StringMap ;
}
```

Issues.Title: slow performance on google page speed due to zone.js
Issues.Body:
I Use angular7 as ssr, and we found out that our application has heavy and serious problems with google page speed and all the issues are funnelling to zone.js

Page speed complain about the script valuation is too high, after breaking down the app, we found the issues were related to polyfills, however, polyfills only containing

```
  import 'zone.js/dist/zone.js';  // Included with Angular CLI.
  import 'classlist.js/classList.min.js';
  import 'web-animations-js/web-animations.min.js';
```

then what we did was totally remove all the content on polyfills file, leave it empty, and add those files, directly from a cdn on the bottom of index.html as:

```
<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/zone.js/0.9.1/zone.min.js"></script>
<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/classlist/1.2.201711092/classList.min.js"></script>
```

and the result was the same, the page speed still complaining about script valuation, however, we manage to reduce 50% of the script valuation, however, still and is really bad.

we were using a zone.js@0.8.10 then we upgrade to latest but nothing. Same result.

In fact, this is affecting all our apps no matter if we build as aot or server-side render, the result is the same.

Does anyone know how to solve this issue with page speed? Our ranking is below 20 over 100 as SSR.

This doesn't make any sense, it supposes to be faster, not slower?
I also try
`<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/zone.js/0.9.1/zone-evergreen.min.js"></script>`

Issues.Title: De-Optimize bundle size when needed. Lazy Loading, common.js
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [x] build
```

my feature request would be a regression of this feature: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/6204

When I declare "stuff" (pipes, directives, components, services) in **AT LEAST TWO** lazy loaded modules a optimization takes places and the "stuff" ends up in **common.js** bundle.

That's desired in most cases, but ...

### Description

Lets take this architecture:


```
root.module

lazy1.module
    secretComponent
    secretDirective

lazy2.module
    secretComponent
    secretDirective
```

this will result in

```
common.js
    secretComponent
    secretDirective
```

my **desired outcome** would be redundant code duplication:

```
no secrets in common.js

lazy1.chunk.js
    secretComponent
    secretDirective

lazy2.chunk.js
    secretComponent
    secretDirective
```

The trivia behind this is that my webserver can block the serving of lazyModules based on auth. and I don't want unauth. users to get the sources for `secret.* "stuff"`.

How can I control what "stuff" lands inside common.js.

### Describe the solution you'd like

My first reaction would be an additional parameter in the modules decorator:


```
. . .
  declarations: [ 
    secretComponent
    secretDirective],
  imports: [MaterialModule],
  providers: [
    secretService
  ],
  bootstrap: [secretComponent],

  keepInModule: [
    secretComponent,
    secretDirective,
    secretService,
  ]
. . .
```

Code declarations that are always added to `keepInModule` will not end up in common.js but will be duplicated to the lazyModulesChunks.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?

Not sure how to archive this with angular-cli

### Some thoughs :boom: 

Since we could provide a service `secretService` solely in let say "secretComponent" we probably need something like `keepInComponent` ... not sure how to handle this case ...

Issues.Title: Datepicker required validation is wrong
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

**_StackBlitz_** example: 

[https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-x2g8lj?file=app%2Fdatepicker-overview-example.ts](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-x2g8lj?file=app%2Fdatepicker-overview-example.ts)

Steps to reproduce:
1. Enter any invalid date value, like `jjj`
2. `date.errors.required` is always `true` for any invalid, non-empty value
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

Like with any other Angular Material component, using `Validators.Required`, `date.errors.required` should be `true` ONLY when the datepicker value is EMPTY!

```html
  <mat-form-field>
    <input matInput [matDatepicker]="picker" placeholder="Choose a date" required formControlName="date">
    <mat-datepicker-toggle matSuffix [for]="picker"></mat-datepicker-toggle>
    <mat-datepicker #picker></mat-datepicker>
  </mat-form-field>
```

```ts
    this.form = this.formBuilder.group({
      date: ['', Validators.required]
    });
```

So, for any non-empty invalid value, instead of:

```html
  <small *ngIf="date.errors?.required && !date.errors?.matDatepickerParse && date.touched" class="mat-warn">Date is required
  </small>
  <small *ngIf="date.errors?.matDatepickerParse && date.touched" class="mat-warn">
    Date is invalid
  </small>
```

there should be:

```html
  <small *ngIf="date.errors?.required && date.touched" class="mat-warn">Date is required
  </small>
  <small *ngIf="date.errors?.matDatepickerParse && date.touched" class="mat-warn">
    Date is invalid
  </small>
```

Also, instead of:

```json
{ "required": true, "matDatepickerParse": { "text": "jjj" } }
```

there should be:

```json
{ "matDatepickerParse": { "text": "jjj" } }
```

as a value of `date.errors` object.

`matDatepickerParse` is a strange concept. Using a custom datepicker validator should be allowed instead of it.

#### Actual Behavior

For invalid non-empty values, this is the control errors object:

```json
{ "required": true, "matDatepickerParse": { "text": "jjj" } }
```

#### Environment

```console
Angular CLI: 8.2.0
Node: 12.8.0
OS: darwin x64
Angular: 8.2.0
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic

Issues.Title: dialog: example prompts should follow Material Design guidance
Issues.Body:
I just noticed while looking at the overview of the Dialog component that the code sample illustrating dialog structure directives did not follow the Material Design guidelines regarding dialogs and alert dialogs.

For dialogs, avoid ambiguous questions as "Are you sure ?" (even though I'm aware that the dialog's title is "Delete all", but then we could just ask "Delete all elements ?" as a title).
Since the provided dialog surely resembles an alert dialog, the example should also provide some explicit action labels, like "Cancel" and "Delete" instead of "No" and "Yes".

I believe the examples provided in Angular Material's documentation should reflect Material Design guidelines.
I usually expect documentation examples to follow best practices, especially regarding a library as serious as Angular Material.
